content.description: It's 5.6 I have no idea where the crux is. Lichen covered jug after lichen covered jug.
content.protection: Passive gear and a variety of smaller cams. No anchor, but you can easily traverse over to the anchors of the neighboring route.
content.location: Climber's left side of the slab to the left of Porter for Recorder. Look for obvious jugs to the left of a right facing ramp. Lower down.

content.description:
A very nice route that goes up to an interesting crack. Great sun exposure all day.

A direct start (recommended) has two bolts going up a slab. The original start is to the right, up a crack.

Climb up to a ledge, then reach the crack system. Climb it to a corner under a roof, traverse left, and finish up the anchor.
content.protection: Standard single rack. Two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location:
This route is at "The Tip" of Long Point. The climb is only reachable during low water season (late fall until early spring).

Directions on the approach are in the 2nd edition of New River Rock Climbs.

content.description: A great technical route that utilizes a wide range of climbing moves. The early crux requires balance and timing. The middle is almost requires bouldery movements. And the top is made easier if you can hand and foot jam. This route is a must do for the grade.
content.location: Two right of Tongue Lashing

content.description: Begin under the cow formation and find your way up through crimps, high-steps and long reaches for average height people
content.location: First bolted line left of Holstein 5.9 trad route.  It is designated by the iconic Cow formation in the rock.

content.description: Ride the handcrack until it turns out and to the right. Follow it to obtain jugs for the traverse out left on to generous chicken heads/grippy nubs and the i m to  bolt ancher
content.protection: single rack to 4.5 inch to good variety of small gear
content.location: Starts in an iron-plated corner just to the right of the bolted line, "Turkey on the Ridge (5.11c)".

content.description: Start in a small dihedral and muscle off the ground. Traverse left to the base of the arete. Climb on the left side of the arete on dirt, lichen and more dirt passing one bolt at the top. Would be better if it was cleaner.
content.protection: An assortment of cams, 1 bolt, bolted anchors
content.location: In between Holy Gail 11c and Chopping Bloc 12a. It's the obvious arete feature past the huge roof.

content.description:
More excellent lakebed stone on this one. Start out on somewhat dirty rock, making large moves between small edges followed by a dynamic move just above the 2nd bolt. Alternatively, you can climb the easy corner crack a few feet to the right and traverse back in.

At the first roof, bear right and make another lengthy traverse back left to the fourth bolt. what follows is more 5.11 climbing, punctuated by a very distinct crux involving bad crimps, a mono-like crimp/pocket/slot, and the most comically bizarre feature you'll ever use on route.

Post crux, more 5.11 climbing on well featured stone leads to the anchors.

Seriously, this route is amazing. Plus, the namesake feature is one of the oddest, lewdest holds you'll see at the New. Do it!
content.location: First line of bolts to the right of Chopping Block's arête.

content.description:
This fantastic, improbably steep route route ascends some more of the brilliant white stone of the Lakebed.

Start preclipped (I advise two bolts), and hop to a shelf. After a juggy traverse deposits you at the base of an arete, engage in a surprise crux section up this feature that ends with a wild drive-by dyno to snag a sharp-lipped jug. Traverse left here (Michael Boltin' branches right), clip bolt three, and then wander left over a bulge before coming back into the bolt line at bolt 4.

The next section looks blank, but fear not: a perfectly placed jug pocket allows relatively easy passage. Further steep hauling on good holds leads to one final big move, and then the anchors.

This route is a gem. Go do it.
content.location: In the Beach area of Long Point. From the access gully, head climber's left for a couple of minutes until you see the steep buttress that holds Aryan Race, Michael Boltin' (13a), and Redneck Logic (13a). Aryan Race is the steepest leftmost line.

content.description: Short left angling ramp to the lichen covered face above. Crux is the lichen mess.
content.location: This is climbers left of Porter for Recorder along with several other easy climbs.

climbs.name: Sun Glory
climbs.fa: Gene Kistler , Eddie Begoon, & Doug Houghton

content.description: Another fantastic line out at long point. Start with some interesting balance moves up through the fat roll slopers to a small ledge. Climb up through the small corner system utilizing some hidden full pad edges up to the final corner system that wants to open you up like a barn door. Super fun and pretty easy for the grade.
content.protection: 5 bolts with a 2 bolt anchor. Will take a blue tcu sized piece between bolt 3 and 4.
content.location: Walk climber's left from the beach access for about 15 minutes, past chopping bloc. Before holy grail there is a long slab. This climb is to the right of that slab. Lower down.

content.description: Look for the well bolted line left of "Opium of the People".  The route starts on a fin, then follows a overhanging thin seam (crux) and through a high roof.
content.location: The Movie Screen alcove, directly across from the Movie Screen itself.  It is just right of a small cave and the prominent arete of Kirkules (13a).

content.description: Starts up a juggy right angling ramp, after this trend up the face to the left set of anchors.
content.location: This is climbers left of Porter for Recorder along with several easier climbs.

content.description: Handcrack on more great lake rock.  Ride the crack until the obvious ledge (beware of mini-fridge sized rock that wobbles).  Ride the left arcing crack another 15ft until a 2-bolt anchor.  Fun cool down climb for those who brought the rack down.
content.location: Next trad line left of Penance cave, before Redneck Logic

content.description:
Begins on a black jug-rail and progresses up and left into a slightly overhanging crack. The crack itself is best for gear as there are better holds on the left wall of the crack.  Once the angle retreats climb straight up the face on good holds to bolt anchor near the shrubs at the top.

Be careful with the rope that it doesn't get sucked into the crack.  There's a finger sized cam that can act as a directional just up and left of the crack.
content.location: The Beach, climber's right of the Arete with Scientific Paws.

content.description:
A pretty decent climb that goes right up the prominent arete. The gear is a little sparse in places.

Start in the wide crack, and reach a ledge. Climb the prow straight up, reaching two cool mantle moves in a row.

There is no anchor, but it is possible to traverse right to the Wendigo anchors, or up to the trees at the cliff top. Don't forget to place a directional.
content.protection: Mostly small pro. This climb might be PG13.
content.location: Directly left of Wendigo, climbs up the prominent arete.

content.description: The crux is the first 2 bolts and is pretty contrived. The upper section climbs pretty well and has some fun moves between a large variety and selection of holds.
content.location: Climber's left of the wet slab approach. Look for a mini roof with chossy looking moves up to a first bolt. Lower down.

content.description: The crux is getting off the ground on this beautiful arete. Starting on the right side is 11d and the left side is around 11a. Both sides are fun and lead up to some interesting climbing up top.
content.protection: 6 bolts maybe with a 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Walk climber's left from the beach access past big bang and it's the first arete!

climbs.name: Route with a Ranger
climbs.fa: Monty Fuss, Austin Joseph Freidrich Fuss

content.description: This route will be good after two more people climb to knock back the crack. The 5.9+ grade takes into consideration the state that the route was in when the FA was established. Once cleaned up the route will likely be a 5.8 or 5.9-. Sling the tree to rap off or run it to the top and rap from there.
content.protection: This is mostly hand sized, along with a standard nut set, heavy on larger nuts. No anchors up top rap off of tree.
content.location: This is to the cliff before Movie Screen Project and there are two routes (climber's right). A trad climb and a 5.11b.

content.description: The route starts on the left side of the face. Stick clipping is highly recommended because there is a difficult, technical boulder problem necessary to get to the high first bolt. After that initial crux, a dynamic move to the big hueco leads into a few bolts of very enjoyable mid-12 climbing.  Another crux comes trying to pull the roof.
content.location: This is the grey face to the right of Michael Boltin’.  There is probably a cheater stack at the start on the left and possibly a second one directly below the first bolt for those with a short stick clip.

content.description: This route is really a great route but is not good for people where 5.11 is their limit. Climb through some mud covered rock to some not so fun climbing. Clip the third bolt and then start looking for some gear placements, because without them you would come very close to the ground if you fell and the climbing is not that easy. This route seems pretty sustained but the spread out bolt job makes a lot of people shy away from it. It's pretty sustained but AFTER you clip the fourth bolt you get some very interesting and super fun moves through the small and sharp crimps. Clip the last bolt and then run about 15 feet to the anchors, for short people you are going to be in a spot to either crimp and high step or jump to a flat rail. Head to the chains and realize you won't ever do this thing again.
content.protection: 5 bolts with a 2 bolt anchor. Take some smaller gear for the bad runouts.
content.location:
About 100 yards to the left of the slab approach.

Lower down.

content.description:
Wow. Wow. Wow. This is a contender for best 5.11 in the area. The first two bolts were already there when Mikey finished it off, so don't judge him for those two. Well actually never mind that; judge him all day. The second bolt is pretty committing so be careful. After that make your way up the arete to the first boulder problem that utilizes perfectly placed feet, a sidepull and some CRIMPS! No worries though, jugs aren't that far away. From here dance your way up to a slabby area with a slap-you-in-the-face-if-5.11-is-your-limit-crux. Make a few more moves through some horizontals and pull the last roof to clip the chains. This route is wet at the top if it's rained a lot lately, but it's still doable. This is an absolute MUST DO and to me rivals every other 5.11 I have been on here. Beautiful rock, movement, goes to the top of the cliff, and the location couldn't get any better. If you want to know how the route got it's name go buy Mikey's book

here

.
content.location: Come down the water covered slab in the middle of long point and walk climbers left for 5 minutes until you come to a beautiful left facing arete. This is it.

content.description: Climb three bolts of moderate flake features into a cryptic and thin slab crux. A nice runout on easy climbing leads to another mini crux, a lip traverse, and a ledge to pull before the anchors. The top is a bit dirty right now but you have what you need. Suggest extending the last few draws to help with rope drag.
content.location: Bolted line near some small boulders - climber's right from Serial Driller. The first bolt is near a thin seam just above the usual water line.

content.description: I can't believe I keep climbing routes at long point that are this good. STICK CLIP the first bolt and start about 12 feet to the right. Climb up through the corner to a mega jug then get your techy traverse on. Once at the first bolt pull up through the sandpaper-like rock and use the finger lock with some good holds intermingled. Clip the second bolt and then make a few lock offs to the corner above then pull the roof onto the slab. The top of this thing gets runoff and can be quite dirty; all of the holds are there but can be hard to hold on to.
content.protection: 6 bolts with a 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Climbers left from the beach access about 50 yards past big bang and right past scientific paws. You will see the beautiful white rock and the traverse.

content.description: Climb up through an ever engaging left leaning crack. The crux on this thing seems to be getting to the 4th bolt, mantle, or use some small holds and get up on it. After that either head to the right onto the slab or up and left to the big flake and then onto the slab. Good route and seems pretty soft for the grade.
content.protection: 4 bolts and maybe some finger sized pieces for the run to the 3rd bolt. 2 bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: Locate the movie theater screen and it's across the drainage ditch to the right of the arete. Lower down.

content.description: This route climbs like a sport route. Start on the face 50 ft. left of Non Sequitur on a hearty jug, continuously moving up and left through jugs, utilizing a few crimps and water groove features along the way aiming, for a horizontal seam at about half height. From here get out your guns and pump over the roof on some bulbous holds. From here, link weaknesses in the rock to the bolted anchors.
content.protection: Standard NRG rack with doubles in .4 and .5.
content.location:
50-75 feet left of non sequitur

Anchors can be tricky to see from the ground

content.description: Short roof crack. Anchor is at the end of the side section but it looks like interesting climbing all the way to the top of the cliff. Anyone know if this has been completed???
content.protection: Bolted Anchor.  Small hands to wide stuff
content.location: Climbers left directly after Aryan Race. Pretty obvious wide roof crack.

content.description: Book says to begin in a right facing corner but seems to mainly be done starting on the slab to its left and traversing ~4ft right to gain the small arete/flake.  No substantial gear until a weakness in the rock begins about 15 ft up.   If you're creative and skilled enough you can "slot-clip" a nut that might protect a fall.  Once there plug a solid cam and continue up the crack system that trends up and slightly right, eventually giving way to really fun climbing and a though-provoking final 15 ft up lightening-white rock.  Fun climb if you have the rack.
content.protection: Micro to #3 camalot, take some extra finger sizes.
content.location: Next trad line left of Big Bang

content.description: This thing is great! It starts with some fun lay back moves to a small amount of easy finger jamming. After that you pull up to a good stance and figure out how to get up on the ledge. From there climb up the through the lichen covered slab to the anchors.
content.protection: A single set of cams from fingers to hands with a set of nuts will suffice. 2 bolt anchor.
content.location: One of many trad routes between Liturgy and Holy Grail. It starts about 30 feet to the left of Holy Grail.

content.description: Obvious corner crack, often dirty. William's guidebook has this at 8+, 1-star but it seems that grade only represents the crack portion. At the standing rest about 45-50ft up, the chimney and stemming moves are a bit more technical and delicate than an 8+ grade would warrant.  If this was cleaned up and an bolt anchor right under the lip, it would be one for people to come here for!
content.protection: No Anchor. to protect comfortably, bring #0.3-#4 with doubles in #1-#3. You could use this as an excuse to bring the #5,6,7,8 haha, it would surely take them but its not necessary. There is a grouping trees about 6ft back from the lip that was suitable for a rope anchor/rappel as of Nov 2020. I suggest top-down belaying the follower, then both rapping off the tree.
content.location: Directly right of Redneck Logic and Aryan Race.

content.description: Start in some cool (though sometimes silty) huecos.  The crux comes at the third bolt, when you encounter a bulge and the huecos disappear.  After the crux, it is enjoyable 5.9 jughauling to the top.
content.location: Distinctive line just upstream (climber's right) of the slab/fixed line descent.  Look for the bolt line that starts through an obvious line of huecos, just before a massive roof.

content.description: Climb the first four bolt of "Crocodiles are Coming" then climb little to the right passing two more bolts. In the top, step left to the "Crocodiles are Coming" bolt anchor.

This route is so rad! The gem of Long Point and a must do if you are in the area. There are a few tough parts but the meat of the climb is up high. Height helps quite a bit down low, but you may be cursing that height as you eat your knees with highsteps higher up.
content.location: The climb is directly across from the iconic Movie Screen, the climb follows an arete left of Stumbling Dice.

content.description:
This is one of the best single-pitch crack routes I've done, and I'm surprised that it's not on here yet. As Mike says in the guidebook, this is the showpiece crack climb of the Lake Region, with flawless rock and lots of unique, complex movement. Thin fingers and good body position awareness helpful...

As with many routes that I post on MP, there is a story behind this one. As most climbers will know, we lost two shining lights this year; Inge Perkins and Hayden Kennedy. Hayden was a good friend to so many, and when we all saw how happy he and Inge were we were elated for them. A pivotal memory I have of the two of them is looking over during the finale performance of the best 80s cover band I've ever seen, playing Prince's "Purple Rain" at Zack and Tara's wedding. The rendition was unbelievable. At some point, dancing with my wife at the time, I nudged her and motioned with my head to look at Hayden and Inge. They were dancing and holding each other in a way that was a perfect illustrations of love, the epitome of innocence and tenderness.  Such a tragic loss. If you don't know about these two and their incredible lives, you would do well by yourself to find out who they were.

Well, Inge participated in the deepwater solo competition that was put on this past summer at the lake, on-sighting this route along the way to her victory. You can see a wonderful film about the event here;

https://www.climbing.com/videos/wild-and-wonderful-west-virginias-psicoroc-deep-water-soloing-competition/

From the conversations I've had with local folks who organized and participated in the event, Inge made a huge impression on the Fayetteville climbing community with her kind, wise and gentle nature, as well as her tenacity and undeniable climbing ability. When I decided to shoe up for this thing at the end of a long day, it was to try and honor and live up to the legacy that she and Hayden left for us. At every point on the route's semi-desperate stemming that I wanted to take or let go, I kept moving because I could recall Inge being on this route, taking it to the chains. As I made the final amazing moves out the roof to the anchor, I almost cried.

I knew Hayden far better than I did Inge. However, they were undoubtedly two of a kind. It meant a great deal to me to channel Hayden's laid-back approach with Inge's never-give-in attitude to send this thing first go. They were two Bodhisattvas, sent here to show us the way. Their lights burned fast and bright, and like the rays of those distant burned out stars in the night sky, it will take many years before the light fades...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UtF6Jej8yb4
content.protection: I started with the two bolts of the neighboring sport climb, then used quadruples in the blue TCU/red c3 range, as well as a couple of medium stoppers. You'll also need a few less-than-tips pieces and a finger-sized cam or two to protect the final moves to the anchor. Nothing bigger than a .5 BD is needed.
content.location: Tips crack in a left facing corner just above the water line. It's front and center to the climber's right of the "slab" approach, just before you round the corner to the "Movie Screen". Once you see it it's unmistakable.

content.description: Left most sport climb? Big hole down low, then there's a stretch of brainy rock.
content.location: Look for the cool brainy section around the 3rd bolt.

content.description: Climb the white rock ramp up and mantle onto the slab. Clip the sketchy first bolt and step around onto the land of lichen. From here high step, crimp and split your way up through what seems to be a never ending forest of lichen. Make a committing move out over the top of the route with a lot of air under your feet and clip the anchors! Check out the view! This route could use a lot more traffic to clean it up some.
content.location:
The obvious arete climber's left from Chopping Bloc that has a very high and sketchy first bolt.

Lower down.

climbs.name: Honemeisters
climbs.fa: Gene Kistler , Eddie Begoon, & Doug Houghton

content.description: The crux comes at you right after the first bolt. After that the climb lets up a good bit. It involves a long reach blindly and then placing your gear. After that follow the bolt line up the lichen covered slab past a few more bolts. Once at the top traverse over to sun glory's anchors.
content.protection: The book says 4 bolts with a 2 bolt anchor, but I believe there were 5 bolts with a bolt at the top for a directional to share the anchors with sun glory. 2 finger sized pieces and single hand sized piece will suffice for gear.
content.location: Walk climber's left from the beach access for about 15 minutes, past chopping bloc. Before holy grail there is a long slab. This climb is to the right of that slab up the obvious arete. Lower down.

content.description: Moderate sport route that has a bit of everything.
content.location: You'll see a big flake around the 2nd/3rd bolt.

content.description: The first bolt is missing a hanger.   You can climb up the start of Tapeworm, 5.9 to the right and then traverse in left to join the climb below the second bolt.   After the traverse, climb up and make some reachy moves to a horizontal.  Head up and right aiming for the right edge of the arete near the top.   From the last bolt, figure out a good sequence to get up to the shuts and clip them (crux).
content.protection: 6 bolts, shuts.  If you traverse in from Tapeworm, #1-#3 camalots work well to protect the crack.
content.location: From the beach descent trail, head left (facing the lake) for about 70 yards.  There will be 2 sport lines next to each other, this is the right line.

content.description: Climb through the first two bolts on sketchy mud-covered holds until you are above the water line. From here work your up the arete utilizing a cool rock over onto the left face and some moves through crimps to an awkward roof. From here reach out right to a hold on the arete and bump to a jug. Pull around and up, clip the bolt and one last lock off leads to the anchors. Pretty fun and a good warmup for some of the harder routes around. I gave this route PG-13, because blowing the second clip would end with a climber on the ground and the rock through that section is fragile and covered in old dry mud.
content.location: From the slab rope walk climber's left for about 25 yards and it's the obvious right-facing arete. Lower down.

content.description: The book says that this is a 5.7, which it is not unless you lower from the first bolt. Otherwise it goes at about 5.9 with 2 bolts. A super fun line and I feel like the crux is going from the first to second bolt up at the very top.
content.location: Directly to the left of Blood Flower, up the obvious crack. Lower down.

content.description: Begin in the white off-width and climb up the corner. You will encounter a singular bolt on the left that leads you up to the beginning of the heavily textured and juggy face. Continue up the face one of many ways until you reach a bolt anchor.
content.protection: Bolt Anchor, one bolt on route
content.location: On the opposite side of the small buttress as Turn and Cough.  Designated by a short, 20ft off width and a single bolt on the left side of the dihedral, where the climber traverses left up and on to the face of the wall. Right of Sausage Wallet and Turn and Cough. Just before the arete that makes up the left side of the Movie Screen Wall.

content.description: Make your way up licheny holds to the beautiful seam (don’t miss the crimp up and left). The next 30 feet are a dream of perfect finger pods with plenty of options on the face for feet. Thug out the roof using a perfect, albeit hard-to-see, pocket before finishing with a victory romp up easier terrain.
content.protection: Thin fingers for the seam, thin hands up top. Bolted anchors.
content.location: Obvious seam left of Spartacus

content.description:
First route that you encounter when you exit the corridor to get to the point base. Good route land accessible when the lake is full. Start on a rail, to a crack/rail system straight up. The line diverges left at bolt four to disks. Step right a couple of feet, fight the pump, and clip the anchors off a generous edge.

Another route at bolt 4 diverges right but does not appear to have anchors.
content.protection: 6 bolts and anchors with rap rings; can be accessed from above to set up a TR
content.location: Near the point, west facing, near the exit of the corridor.

content.description: The climb is a broken crack system in the middle of Long Point. The anchors sit in a capped roof.
content.protection: Standard small nut set, or passive nut set. Protects very well.
content.location: The route is tucked in a small alcove and climbs the obvious broken splitter beneath a small roof.

content.description: Boulder problem crux followed by easy climbing. Bolt line left of Liturgy

I can't say I have seen better rock. Start with pulling on your rope (A0) until you get up and established on this beauty. Start with some interesting moves around the corner to the left and up. Utilize flat edge crimps mixed with sandpaper like rock until you are faced with some long moves to a classic NRG flat jug and sidepull/undercling. Use the holds just mentioned or find an alternative small crimp and go for it and figure out how to use all of the feet and get established up on a heinous micro crimp. Hold on, bust a move and clip the anchors.
content.location: Walk climber's left past Big Bang, and you will past a beautiful white arete/face with two lines going up it. After that you will shortly come a low roof with single bolt on it. The route starts here and goes left around the arete. Lower down.

content.description: Start standing on a big Boulder boulder a bit to a jug clip a bolt an bust right, to the base of the crack. Get to dancing up the seam to a hard to clip bolt.  Get up to the roof and be granted a good rest. Pull the roof to Tackle some tricky white rock and make way to the anchors.   mike gives it a 12a  it’s a stout one.   Excellent moves and stone
content.location: Three or four bolt lines Climber’s left of flake and bake. Two routes down from boss eagle.

content.description: The business on this beaut is down low getting past the bolt. After that you can get in a few tcus throughout the small corner. Pull up through some horizontals and get ready for a final 11+ red point crux at the very top. Pull through this and then wander up the lichen covered crack and slab to the anchors. So so good.
content.protection: 1 bolt down low with a 2 bolt anchor. Single set of cams.
content.location: Directly to the left of Chopping Block. Lower down.

content.description: Sandbagged 12b's aren't just for Endless Wall! Very sustained, intricate, and beautiful route. Definitely height dependent with a final redpoint-crux pop at the very top.
content.location: Just to the right, and sharing the same first bolt of Porter For Recorder.

content.description: Beautiful white rock that has unreal texture. I think the crux is getting establish out the initial corner system. After that it has some easy climbing up to a few semi-long reaches between good holds. Ends under the big roof.
content.location: Walk 30 seconds climber's left from the beach access and locate the obvious big white roof. Lower down.

content.description: Start by pulling the roof, then head up the crack above. There are 3 bolts on the upper face before the anchor.
content.protection: A single rack up to ~#3, maybe a #4, 3 bolts + anchors.
content.location: To the right of the sport routes.

content.description: A must do climb if you are on this side of the lake!  Probably light for the grade but the fun factor is very high.   Start at the base of the crack in the 10 foot high section of rotten rock to get a stance.  Plug some gear and figure out a way to reach the huge jug on the overhanging face and then pull through the bulge and gain another stance (crux).  From here, pull a small overhang and it's nothing but huge plated jugs to the top.  The gear is abundant throughout the entire climb.
content.protection: Mostly stoppers and small cams.  There's a few spots for some larger cams up to 4", but you don't need them.   Shuts.
content.location: From the beach approach, head right (facing the lake) for about 100 yards until you reach the first nice section of cliff.  Walk along the cliff passing a sport line and a dirty 5.7 (Flake and Bake).  When you reach Big Bang, you'll know it.

content.description: Arete right to the "Wrapped in Tyvek".
content.location: Right of "The Beach".

content.description: The first route you will encounter on your righthand side if you take the Beach approach. The route starts at the top of a boulder and follows a leaning crack. The route is almost comically short, but it has some nice movement for a warm up or cool down (or a short jaunt if you're trying to pack in a bunch of pitches for your birthday).
content.location: If you are taking the standard approach trail to the Beach, this is the first route you will encounter on your right hand side.

content.description: An easy climb with one hard move. Make a big jump or a static reach at the first bolt and enjoy the jug haul to the top.
content.location: Straight up the middle of the face left of Cousteau's Crux

content.description: Crux is at the bottom getting over the little roof between the first and second bolt.  Long reach to one pad rail.  Move off that to fun climbing above. Route was named after Eric Workman.  He is the WV State Trooper that was killed August 31, 2012.  He was a rock climber as well and this is just a small way to honor him.  His unit number was 665.
content.protection: 5 bolts plus anchors.  Shares anchors with 204 which is a little to the right.
content.location: This route is about 100yds down the lake from the end of Long Point.  There are now 3 sport routes on this little wall.  Two have SS silver bolts and hangers and one has black hangers.  I am not sure who put up the route with the black anchors.

content.description: We bolted this route from a boat and we will revisit it once the lake lowers.  The fist couple bolts are the crux.  Pull a little roof and enjoy the sustained climbing to the shared anchors of 665.  This route was named after Marshall Bailey.  He was a WV State Trooper that was shot and killed on August 28th, 2012.  This was just a small way to honor one of our fallen heroes.
content.location: This climb is to the right of 665 and to the left of the sport climb that has the black hangers (not sure who put it up).  It is about 100 yards down the lake from Long Point.  We put 665 and 204 under the roof in climbers chalk but I am sure that won't last.
